article.title: Dana_Plato

template.arg: Plato as Kimberly on ''Diff'rent Strokes'', in 1979

article.paragraph: Dana Michelle Plato(November 7, 1964 – May 8, 1999) was an American actress, notable for playing the role ofKimberly Drummondon the U.S. televisionSituation comedysitcomDiff'rent Strokesfrom 1978 to 1986.cite webhttp://movies.nytimes.com/person/57045/Dana-PlatoDana Plato - About This Person - Movies & TV - NYTimes.com[[The New York Times]]2015-01-26After leaving the cast ofDiff'rent Strokes, Plato attempted to establish herself as a working actress, with mixed success: she worked sporadically in made-for-TV movies and in independent films, and also did voice-over work. At age 34, after years of struggling with poverty and substance abuse, Plato died from an overdose of prescription drugs.cite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/1999/05/10/arts/dana-plato-34-star-of-diff-rent-strokes.html’Dana Plato, 34, Star of 'Diff'rent Strokes'[[The New York Times]]May 10, 19992015-08-23
article.heading: Life and career
196477: Childhood and career beginnings
article.paragraph: Plato was bornDana Michelle Strainon November 7, 1964 inMaywood, California, to Linda Strain, an unwed teenager who was already caring for an 18-month-old child. Seven months after her birth, in June 1965, she was adopted by Dean Plato, who owned a trucking company, and his wife Florine "Kay" Plato.cite webhttp://ssdi.rootsweb.ancestry.comRootsWeb: Database Indexancestry.com26 January 2015She was raised in theSan Fernando Valley. When she was three, her adoptive parents divorced, and she lived with her mother.cite journalGliattoTomMay 24, 1999http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20128316,00.htmlLittle Girl Lost[[People (magazine)|People]]51190093-7673

Plato began attending auditions with her mother when she was very young. From the age of seven, she began appearing in television commercials; she reportedly appeared in over 100 commercials for companies as diverse asKentucky Fried Chicken,Dole Food CompanyDole, andAtlantic Richfield. Plato later claimed that she was offered two highly sought-after movie roles: the role ofspiritual possessionpossessedchildRegan MacNeilin the 1973 filmThe Exorcist (film)The Exorcistand the starring role inLouis Malle's 1978 filmPretty Baby (film)Pretty Baby. According to Plato, her mother vetoed both jobs, either fearing that Plato would beTypecasting (acting)typecast, or subjected to unsavory subject matter.However,ExorcistcreatorWilliam Peter Blattysaid he had "no such recollection" of Plato being offered the role. Plato made her film debut at the age of 12 in the 1977 horror filmReturn to Boggy Creek.cite web[[The New York Times]]http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/41121/Return-to-Boggy-Creek/castReturn to Boggy CreekOther early credits includedExorcist II: The Heretic(1977) andCalifornia Suite (film)California Suite(1978).

In addition to her acting career, Plato was also an accomplished figure skater; at one point she trained for a possibleOlympic GamesOlympicteam spot. It was during this time that she made a brief appearance on TV'sThe Gong Showand was spotted by a producer who helped her secure what became her most famous acting role, that of Kimberly Drummond onDiff'rent Strokes.According to Plato, her mother decided that she should cut back on her skating in order to focus on the role.
article.heading: 197886:Diff'rent Strokes
article.paragraph: MainDiff'rent StrokesDiff'rent Strokesdebuted onNBCin 1978, becoming an immediate hit. The show features Phillip Drummond (Conrad Bain), a wealthy white widower in New York City who adopts two black boys after the death of their parents. Plato played Kimberly, Drummond's teenage daughter, who at the start of the show becomes the sister of the two boys, Willis (Todd Bridges) and Arnold (Gary Coleman). Plato appeared on the show from 1978 until 1984 and again from 1985 to 1986; during her tenure the show appeared on two different networks.

During her years onDiff'rent Strokes, Plato struggled with drug and alcohol problems. She admitted to drinking and usingcannabis (drug)cannabisandcocaine, and she suffered an overdose ofdiazepamwhen she was 14.In December 1983, Plato moved in with her boyfriend, rock guitaristLanny Lambert. The couple married on April 24, 1984, and their only child, Tyler Edward Lambert, was born on July 2, 1984.cite webhttp://www.familytreelegends.com/records/39461Free Family Tree, Genealogy and Family History - MyHeritagefamilytreelegends.comcite newsLuchinaFisherSheilaMarikarhttp://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/dana-platos-son-tyler-lambert-commits-suicide-mom/story?idGrowing Pains: The Trials and Tribulations of 1980s TV Child StarsABC NewsMay 13, 20102015-08-23During this time, Plato was let go fromDiff'rent Strokesbecause the producers did not feel that a pregnancy would fit the show's wholesome image. Although rumors of drug use and other problems on the set surrounded her dismissal, the producers were adamant that Plato's pregnancy was the only reason her character was written out. She returned for several appearances during the show's seventh and eighth seasons, including an episode that aired on January 17, 1986 and was Plato's final appearance on the show, in which Kimberly suffers from the effects ofbulimia.
article.heading: 198798: AfterDiff'rent Strokes
article.paragraph: After leavingDiff'rent Strokes, Plato attempted to establish herself as a serious actress, but found it difficult to achieve success outside of her sitcom career. She hadbreast implantsand modeled for a June 1989Playboypictorial, but her career remained in stagnation, and she started taking roles in suchB-moviesasBikini Beach Race(1989) andLethal Cowboy(1992). Plato separated from Lambert in January 1988, the same week her mother died ofscleroderma. In desperation over these traumatic events, she signed overpower of attorneyto an accountant who disappeared with the majority of her money, leaving her with no more than $150,000. She claimed that the accountant was never found or prosecuted, despite an exhaustive search, and that he had also stolen more than $11 million of other people's money.

During their March 1990 divorce, Plato lost custody of her son to Lambert and was given visitation rights.She moved to Las Vegas, where she struggled with poverty and unemployment. At one point she worked at a dry-cleaning store, where customers reported being impressed by her lack of airs.On February 28, 1991, she entered a video store, produced a gun, and demanded the money in the register. The clerk called9-1-1911saying, "I've just been robbed by the girl who played Kimberly onDiff'rent Strokes." Approximately 15 minutes after the robbery, Plato returned to the scene and was immediately arrested. The gun was only apellet gunand the robbery netted Plato $164.cite journalSporkinElizabethMarch 24, 1991http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20114736,00.htmlDiff'rent Strokes, Fallen Stars[[People (magazine)|People]]3511Las Vegas entertainerWayne Newtonposted her $13,000 bail.The Death of Dana Platoat Morbidly HollywoodPlato was given five years'probation. She made headlines and became a subject of the national debate surrounding troubled child stars, particularly given the difficulties of herDiff'rent Strokesco-stars Gary Coleman and Todd Bridges. In January 1992, she was arrested again, this time for forging a prescription for Diazepam. She served 30 days in jail for violation of the terms of her probation and entered a drug rehabilitation program immediately thereafter.

In 1992, Plato was one of the first celebrities to star in a video game. The game,Night Trap, was not a great success, but is considered a pioneering title because it was the first game to use live actors, specifically a well-known personality.cite webhttp://www.mobygames.com/game/sega-cd/night-trapMobyGames Page on Night TrapMobyGames2010-08-02It was one of the first video game titles to have mature content and attracted controversy due to its depiction of violence.cite bookSlavenAndyVideo Game Bible, 1985-20022002Trafford Publishing2971-55369-731-6The controversy, along with that surroundingMortal Kombat, eventually led to the creation of theEntertainment Software Rating BoardESRB.cite bookA.V. ClubKlostermanChuckInventory: 16 Films Featuring Manic Pixie Dream Girls, 10 Great Songs Nearly Ruined by Saxophone, and 100 More Obsessively Specific Pop-Culture Lists2009Simon and Schuster911-4165-9473-6

Toward the end of her career, Plato chose roles that could be considerederoticandsoftcore pornographysoftcore.cite newshttp://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/172923/Different-Strokes-The-Story-of-Jack-Jill-and-Jill/overviewDifferent Strokes: The Story of Jack & Jill... and Jill (1997)[[The New York Times]]2014-02-06She appeared nude inPrime Suspect(1989) andCompelling Evidence(1995), and in the softcore erotic dramaDifferent Strokes (film)Different Strokes: The Story of Jack and Jill...and Jill(1997), whose title was changed after filming in order to tie it to Plato's past. Following her appearance in the film, in 1998, Plato appeared in a cover story of the lesbian lifestyle magazineGirlfriends magazineGirlfriends, in which shecoming outcame outas alesbian, although she later recanted.

She became engaged toFred Potts (film director)Fred Pottsa filmmaker and close friend ofJohnny Whitaker, but the romance soon broke up and she returned to drugs.Just before her death, she was engaged to her manager Robert Menchaca, with whom she lived in a motor home inNavarre, Florida.
article.heading: 1999: Final interview and death
article.paragraph: On May 7, 1999, the day before she died, Plato appeared onThe Howard Stern Show. She spoke about her life, discussing her financial problems and her past run-ins with the law. She admitted to being a recovering alcoholic and drug addict, but claimed that she had been sober for more than ten years by that point, and was not using any drugs, with the exception of prescribed painkillers due to the recent extraction of her teeth. Many callers insulted her and questioned her sobriety, which provoked a defiant Plato, who offered to take a drug test on the air. Some callers, as well as hostHoward Stern, came to Plato's defense.Dana Plato's finalinterviewwithHoward Stern

The next day, Plato and Menchaca were returning to California, the couple stopped at Menchaca's mother's home inMoore, OklahomaMoore,Oklahoma, for aMother's Dayvisit.Plato went to lie down inside herWinnebago IndustriesWinnebagomotor home parked outside the house, where she died of an overdose of the painkillerHydrocodone/paracetamolLortaband the muscle-relaxantCarisoprodolSoma. Her death was eventually ruled a suicide.cite journalO'NeillAnne-MarieJune 7, 1999http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20128431,00.htmlSeeking Serenity[[People (magazine)|People]]5120Her body was cremated.cite bookBenoitTodWhere Are They Buried?: How Did They Die? Fitting Ends and Final Resting Places of the Famous, Infamous, and Noteworthy2009Black Dog Publishing2111-57912-822-XEleven years after Plato's death, on May 6, 2010, her son Tyler Lambert died at age 25 inTulsa, OklahomaTulsa, Oklahoma, of a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head.cite newshttp://content.usatoday.com/communities/entertainment/post/2010/05/dana-platos-son-dies-at-age-25/1Dana Plato's son dies at age 25[[USA Today]]May 12, 2010Lambert had reportedly been experimenting with drugs and alcohol.cite journalhttp://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20368636,00.htmlSon of the Late Dana Plato Commits SuicideMesserLesleyMay 13, 2010[[People (magazine)|People]]2010-05-31Johnny Whitaker, Plato's former manager and a family friend, said that Lambert always said he "wanted to be with Mom."
